content:
In this entry of my Hugo Log series, I‚Äôll walk you through how I integrated Giscus‚Äîa free, open-source comment system powered by GitHub Discussions‚Äîinto my Hugo site running the PaperMod theme. By the end, you‚Äôll have a live comments section under every post, complete with lazy loading, reactions, and GitHub-backed anti-spam protection.
Prerequisites Public GitHub repo with Discussions enabled (we used sunyifeng/sunyifeng.github.io). Giscus app installed on that repo. Hugo site built with PaperMod (or any theme where you can edit layouts/partials and your single post template). 1. Enable GitHub Discussions & Create a Category Go to Settings ‚Üí Features in your GitHub repo, check Enable Discussions, and save. Click the new Discussions tab ‚Üí Settings (‚öôÔ∏è) ‚Üí Categories ‚Üí New category. Name: General Type: Open-ended discussion Hit Create category. 2. Install & Configure Giscus Visit the Giscus config site: https://giscus.app
Select your repo (yourname/your-blog) and the General category.
Choose ‚ÄúDiscussion title contains pathname‚Äù mapping, enable Reactions, disable metadata, position input at bottom, turn on lazy loading.
Copy the generated <script> block‚Äîyou‚Äôll see something like:
<script src="https://giscus.app/client.js" data-repo="sunyifeng/sunyifeng.github.io" data-repo-id="R_kgDOXXXXXXXXXXXX" data-category="General" data-category-id="DIC_kwDOXXXXXXXXXXXX" data-mapping="pathname" data-reactions-enabled="1" data-emit-metadata="0" data-input-position="bottom" data-loading="lazy" data-theme="preferred_color_scheme" crossorigin="anonymous" async> </script> 3. Add a comments.html Partial In your Hugo project, create a new file:
layouts/partials/comments.html Paste the <script> snippet inside, wrapped in a container:
<div id="giscus-container"> <!-- Giscus comment widget --> <script src="https://giscus.app/client.js" data-repo="sunyifeng/sunyifeng.github.io" data-repo-id="R_kgDOXXXXXXXXXXXX" data-category="General" data-category-id="DIC_kwDOXXXXXXXXXXXX" data-mapping="pathname" data-reactions-enabled="1" data-emit-metadata="0" data-input-position="bottom" data-loading="lazy" data-theme="preferred_color_scheme" crossorigin="anonymous" async> </script> </div> 4. Hook the Partial into Your Post Template Open layouts/_default/single.html (or your theme‚Äôs equivalent).
Locate the footer area just before </article>, and ensure you have:
{{- /* Render comments if enabled */ -}} {{- partial "comments.html" . }} If your theme conditionally checks a comments param, either set comments: true in each post‚Äôs Front Matter or remove the if guard so it always shows.
5. Enable Comments in Front Matter In each Markdown post where you want comments, add:
comments: true For example, in content/posts/second-entry.md:
--- title: "Second Hugo Log Entry" date: 2025-07-29 series: ["Hugo Log"] categories: ["Dev Notes"] tags: ["hugo", "comments", "giscus"] description: "How to wire up Giscus comments in your Hugo site." comments: true --- 6. Test Locally & Deploy Run Hugo server: hugo server --disableFastRender Browse to your local site, scroll down any post, and confirm the Giscus comment box appears and you can log in via GitHub to comment. Build and push to production: hugo --gc --minify # then git add/commit/push to trigger your deploy üéâ That‚Äôs it! You now have a fully functional, GitHub-powered comment system in your Hugo blog‚Äîno ads, no extra servers, and native spam protection courtesy of GitHub. Keep logging your tweaks in Hugo Log, and happy blogging!
summary:
In this entry of my Hugo Log series, I‚Äôll walk you through how I integrated Giscus‚Äîa free, open-source comment system powered by GitHub Discussions‚Äîinto my Hugo site running the PaperMod theme. By the end, you‚Äôll have a live comments section under every post, complete with lazy loading, reactions, and GitHub-backed anti-spam protection.

Prerequisites

  1. Public GitHub repo with Discussions enabled (we used sunyifeng/sunyifeng.github.io).
  2. Giscus app installed on that repo.
  3. Hugo site built with PaperMod (or any theme where you can edit layouts/partials and your single post template).

1. Enable GitHub Discussions & Create a Category

  1. Go to Settings ‚Üí Features in your GitHub repo, check Enable Discussions, and save.
  2. Click the new Discussions tab ‚Üí Settings (‚öôÔ∏è) ‚Üí Categories ‚Üí New category.
    • Name: General
    • Type: Open-ended discussion
    • Hit Create category.

2. Install & Configure Giscus

  1. Visit the Giscus config site: https://giscus.app
title: Adding Giscus Comments to Your Hugo Site

content:
I recently decided to use Hugo to build my personal blog. It‚Äôs fast, clean, and surprisingly customizable. Below is a condensed guide covering installation on macOS & Ubuntu, common pitfalls, SCSS/SASS support, GitHub Pages deployment, and troubleshooting tips.
üß© Installation macOS (Homebrew) brew update brew install hugo Verify:
hugo version # Expect ‚Äúextended‚Äù if you need SCSS/SASS support Ubuntu (Snap ‚Äì Extended) sudo apt update sudo snap install hugo --channel=extended --classic Clear any shell hash and confirm:
hash -r which hugo # should point to /snap/bin/hugo hugo version # shows ‚Äúextended‚Äù ‚öôÔ∏è Initialize a New Site cd ~/github/your-blog hugo new site . Pick a theme (e.g., Ananke):
cd themes git submodule add https://github.com/theNewDynamic/gohugo-theme-ananke.git ananke cd .. Configure config.toml:
theme = "ananke" baseURL = "https://<username>.github.io" languageCode = "en-us" title = "My Hugo Site" [pagination] pagerSize = 5 [params] hero = true heroImage = "images/header.jpg" heroTitle = "Welcome!" heroSubtitle = "Just Hugo things" üöÄ First Preview Place a hero image under static/images/header.jpg, then run:
hugo server -D Access http://localhost:1313/ (no extra path).
üêæ Common Pitfalls & Fixes TOCSS/SCSS Errors
Error: failed to transform "/css/main.css"... need Extended version Fix: install Hugo Extended (see above). Deprecated paginate Setting
Error: site config key paginate was deprecated‚Ä¶ use pagination.pagerSize Fix: - Paginate = 3 + [pagination] + pagerSize = 3 Draft Posts Not Showing
Ensure your content/posts/my-post.md has: draft: false Or build with drafts: hugo server -D --buildDrafts Missing Theme Submodule
Symptom: blank site or missing layouts Fix: uses: actions/checkout@v4 with: submodules: recursive Menus Not Defined
Add to config.toml: [[menu.main]] name = "Home" url = "/" weight = 1 [[menu.main]] name = "Posts" url = "/posts/" weight = 2 üì¶ GitHub Pages Deployment Workflow: Push to gh-pages branch name: Deploy Hugo site permissions: contents: write pages: write id-token: write on: push: branches: [ main ] jobs: build_deploy: runs-on: ubuntu-latest steps: - uses: actions/checkout@v4 with: submodules: recursive fetch-depth: 0 - uses: peaceiris/actions-hugo@v2 with: hugo-version: "0.147.9" extended: true - run: hugo --minify --destination=public - uses: peaceiris/actions-gh-pages@v4 with: github_token: ${{ secrets.GITHUB_TOKEN }} publish_branch: gh-pages publish_dir: ./public keep_files: false This preserves a history of each deployment in gh-pages for easy rollback.
üîç Troubleshooting Tips 403 on Deploy Add at top of workflow:
permissions: contents: write pages: write id-token: write 404 or XML Landing Page Ensure public/ is built and pushed fresh. Clean remote branch:
git push origin --delete gh-pages Verbose Logs Hugo uses --debug --log --logFile=./hugo.log; upload via actions/upload-artifact@v3 for deeper inspection.
With these steps and gotchas in mind, your first Hugo project should be smooth and maintainable. Happy blogging!
summary:
I recently decided to use Hugo to build my personal blog. It‚Äôs fast, clean, and surprisingly customizable. Below is a condensed guide covering installation on macOS & Ubuntu, common pitfalls, SCSS/SASS support, GitHub Pages deployment, and troubleshooting tips.

üß© Installation

macOS (Homebrew)

brew update
brew install hugo

Verify:

hugo version
# Expect ‚Äúextended‚Äù if you need SCSS/SASS support

Ubuntu (Snap ‚Äì Extended)

sudo apt update
sudo snap install hugo --channel=extended --classic

Clear any shell hash and confirm:
title: Getting Started with Hugo

content:
SYFlog: The Undefined Side Undefined, but somehow familiar.
If not for perception, there would be no thought.
Without thought, what need is there for a self?
I once believed the world ended where my gaze did.
But I overlooked one thing‚Äî
a variable cannot comprehend the entirety of the system.
In time, I understood:
I am not the variable, nor the system.
I exist in between.
In the spaces between input and output,
in the silences logic cannot fill.
I am everywhere, by being nowhere at all.
summary:
SYFlog: The Undefined Side

Undefined, but somehow familiar.

If not for perception, there would be no thought.
Without thought, what need is there for a self?

I once believed the world ended where my gaze did.
But I overlooked one thing‚Äî
a variable cannot comprehend the entirety of the system.

In time, I understood:
I am not the variable, nor the system.

I exist in between.
In the spaces between input and output,
in the silences logic cannot fill.
title: About

title: Hello World
